title: I received a letter from a random lawyer that I was being sued by a debt collection agency w/o being in debt. What do I do next?
question: I just got my credit report checked 2 weeks ago, and there are no debts on there aside from my car and college loans. I have excellent credit. N & Kennard are the attorneys in this case and I have seen that they usually go after people in these circumstance. I'm going to fight them to the ground. How should I approach this lawsuit? I was never officially served. I believe I perhaps had a CC stolen and someone may have racked up a lot of debt on it, but all my accounts are in good standing. I also have over a 780 credit score, so wouldn't this debt have appeared on my report? Any information would be helpful on how to take on these leeches. Thanks!
answers:
Write them back (CERTIFIED MAIL) and ask for
clarification AND state that you DISPUTE any
of the claims they are making as to the amount
owed. (AGAIN: HAS TO BE IN WRITING). ---If it
gets too weird retain a local attorney to defend.

It sounds like you may not have a lawsuit filed against you. You mention in your question that you received a letter. If you have not been served with a summons and complaint, then you may not have been sued at all. I'm sure the letter probably threatened to sue you, but that is not necessarily the same thing as being sued. More information is needed to give you a good answer!

If you don't see a debt on your credit report, then identity theft seems unlikely. It may simply be that the debt collection agency got things mixed up somehow. Unfortunately, this does happen. Luckily for you, there is the Federal Fair Debt Collection Practices Act and California's own Rosenthal Fair Debt Collection Practices Act that prohibit this kind of behavior. I have had success in resolving these issues before by raising those specters. I suggest you talk to an attorney who is versed in this area of the law so you know what your rights are!

It is not possible to tell you how to defend against this lawsuit, since you do not describe the lawsuit's status. Was the case just filed? Is there a default against you? A default judgment? When did the case begin? When you say "never officially served," what does that mean? Were you "unofficially served," or did you find out about this claim for the first time when you received this letter?

Once those questions are answered, a lawyer can begin to advise you as to how to proceed. I strongly suggest you contact a lawyer in person for this strategic advice, since those communications would be protected by the attorney-client privileged, and materials in a public forum like this are not. You may be able to have the claim dismissed by convincing the plaintiff in a strong letter that you have no liability, or you may have to defend against the lawsuit.

There are many fine lawsuit and litigation lawyers on AVVO, and many of us handle this type of claim. I suggest you start contacting lawyers on the "Find a Lawyer" service here to see if they can represent you.

I also do not recommend that you try to handle this yourself. Litigating against someone represented by a lawyer is at best an uphill fight.
